posts.name: FredK
posts.cooked: We’re trying to figure out if we can plug a Rev Magneitc Limit Switch into the Spark Max directly, but are having trouble interpreting this from the Rev Instructions. “Currently, Limit Switch inputs are only supported when using an absolute encoder or an incremental encoder run through the SPARK MAX’s Encoder port. Please note, the limit switch inputs cannot be used at the same time as an Alternate Encoder Mode. The limit switch pins are repurposed for the alternate encoder and are thus disabled.” There is no documentation on the mag limit switch page that shows it can be plugged into the Spark Max, so we’re thinking it is not an option, but want to confirm. We are planning to plug a through bore encoder into a different Spark Max and that seems to be allowed, but it someone could confirm that, we would feel less nervous.

posts.name: Kayla Toll
posts.cooked: You can plug this into the spark max in almost all cases. The note you found about alternate encoder mode is only for quadrature encoders to plug into the top port if you are using the spark max for a brushless motor. You should be able to plug your sensor data wire into the forward or reverse pin on the top of the spark max.

posts.name: FredK
posts.cooked: Do we need an adapter for the 4 pin cable to plug into the 6 pin input on the spark max?

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: The limit switch plugs into the 10 pin 1.27mm pitch connector on the top of the spark max (Rev calls it the Data Port) , not into the 6 pin JST-PH 2.0 pitch connector that the encoder wire uses.

posts.name: James Lyon
posts.cooked: As the previous post said, you want to plug it into the 10-pin “Data Port” connection on top, not the 6-pin connection for the encoder. REV makes a component for this kind of situation. SPARK MAX Data Port Breakout Board - REV Robotics It plugs into the data port connection and breaks out the connections for soldering. It also has 5v outputs for powering the limit switch.

link_counts.title: SPARK MAX Data Port Breakout Board - REV Robotics

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: If you want to make your own cable, this listing from Amazon plugs directly into that port (and when cut in half, 1 cable gives you two spark max’s worth of connectors).

link_counts.title: Amazon.com: Connectors Pro 2-Pack 20cm 7.8 Inches 1.27mm 10P 2x5 F/F Mini Female to Female IDC Connector on 0.635mm Pitch 10 Conductors 20 cm Flat Ribbon Cable : Electronics

posts.name: FredK
posts.cooked:
Thank you. We’re still confused on where to solder the signal wires and can’t find the wiring diagram in the mag limit documentation. Also, does it matter which ground pad to use. PXL_20250221_142918176.MP 1920×2550 567 KB PXL_20250221_142955829 1920×2550 680 KB

PXL_20250221_142918176.MP 1920×2550 567 KB

PXL_20250221_142955829 1920×2550 680 KB

PXL_20250221_142955829 1920×2550 680 KB

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: Both GNDs are surely connected to each other, so there is no electrical difference. Take GND to GND, 3.3V to 3.3V, and the signal on the sensor to either Limit-F or Limit-R (depending on the direction of motion that you want to limit; those are “limit forward” and “limit reverse”).

posts.name: FredK
posts.cooked: Sorry, by signal, do you mean the signal n or or signal n+1 wire?

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
I’ve never personally used that part, but from reading the schematic, it looks like both of those outputs are hard-wired to each other, so they are equivalent electrically.

(The little “dot” means those wires are connected). Screenshot 2025-02-21 at 1.21.44 PM 1512×840 200 KB

Screenshot 2025-02-21 at 1.21.44 PM 1512×840 200 KB

Screenshot 2025-02-21 at 1.21.44 PM 1512×840 200 KB

posts.name: FredK
posts.cooked:
You nailed it. I heard back from rev.

“Ground would go to GND, power to 3.3V, then both n and n+1 for the signal would both be soldered to either the forward or reverse (F or R) limit depending on your application.”
